Yes, much like other drugs and alcohol, cocaine can significantly change an individual’s personality. The reason is simple: drugs alter the brain. They flood the brain with dopamine, a neurotransmitter that is present in regions of the brain that regulate movement, emotion, motivation, and feelings of pleasure. Overtime, cocaine alters critical brain activity and tricks the brain into prioritizing the substance over everything else. Because the brain is consumed by the drug, an individual’s personality drastically changes. Some ways that cocaine alters an individual’s personality and behavior include: - Secrecy - Paranoia - Selfishness - Restlessness - Forgetfulness - Impulsiveness - Becoming abusive - High risk behavior - Low stress tolerance - Frequent mood swings Erratic behavior and negative changes in personality can have devastating effects on an individual’s overall well-being and those who love them. For an individual to reclaim their former self after being affected by substance abuse, they need to be ready to commit to serious lifestyle changes, starting with quitting. Because drugs and alcohol alter the brain, it is impossible for the brain to heal without the individual abstaining from drugs and alcohol.
